Description: Upper body sherd (mended from two fragments) of Corinthian black-figured pottery column-krater with part of handle root; interior: glazed black; exterior: black-figure decoration consisting of tip of horse's muzzle; handle root painted black.
Findspot: Excavated/Findspot: Sanctuary of the Dioskouroi (Naukratis) (The sherd with part of a dedication to the Dioskouroi,1888,0601.751, was found buried in muddy sand under the west wall of Temenos of the Dioskoroi, but the Register gives Temenos of Apollo as find-spot for this sherd.)
Curator's comments: The reconstructed krater includes British Museum 1886,0401.1142, 1886,0401.1006, 1886,0401.1098.a-e, 1886,0401.1098.h, 1886,0401.1102, 1886,0401.1128, 1886,0401.1115, 1886,0401.1145, 1886,0401.1103, 1886,0401.1144, and 1888,0601.751. All that remains of this krater is the upper portion which is rejoined from numerous fragments and plaster cast inserts. Alexandridou appears to give the krater an Attic origin.
Bibliographic references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum (B102.11.2) (part)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GB.027) (Phase 1)
Alexandridou 2011 / The Early Black-Figured Pottery of Attika in Context (c. 630-570BCE) (p. 124) (Naukratis 109)
